the first step in true object oriented programming is understand encapsulation of data and methods in classes. the next is to learn to design a class' methods so that they guarantee the internal state of the data in the class objects at all times and then to prevent access by outside functions which might not obey these state guarantees.
the language does not force object oriented programming on the developer it is up to the developer rigorously attend to this paradigm.

here, you build data structures that emulate the atomic objects. for example, you might want to implement a representation of the time that can be treated as an integer in that you can assign an integer to the time and vice versa.
doing this kind of thing requires that you understand all the operators
